channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Mariupol evacuees reach safety; missiles hit Lviv
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck
item.description: The evacuations from the Azovstal steel plant come as Moscow reportedly prepares to annex Ukrainian territory, including Donetsk, Luhansk and Kherson.

item.title: Defense secretary says U.S. arms being put to ‘good use’ in Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.description: Ukraine's military is challenging Russian forces in the country's south and east, but strikes on civilian targets continue.

item.title: What is happening in Ukraine’s Mariupol, the city under Russian siege?
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger
item.description: Moscow had issued an ultimatum to Ukrainians remaining in the besieged port city: Surrender by midday and your life will be spared. Here’s what to know about Mariupol and the humanitarian catastrophe unfolding there.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Mariupol evacuees reach safety; missiles hit Lviv
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck
item.description: The evacuations from the Azovstal steel plant come as Moscow reportedly prepares to annex Ukrainian territory, including Donetsk, Luhansk and Kherson.

item.title: Defense secretary says U.S. arms being put to ‘good use’ in Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.description: Ukraine's military is challenging Russian forces in the country's south and east, but strikes on civilian targets continue.

item.title: What is happening in Ukraine’s Mariupol, the city under Russian siege?
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger
item.description: Moscow had issued an ultimatum to Ukrainians remaining in the besieged port city: Surrender by midday and your life will be spared. Here’s what to know about Mariupol and the humanitarian catastrophe unfolding there.

item.title: Evacuees from Mariupol steel plant describe brutality of long siege
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck
item.description: Dazed, haunted and traumatized, survivors struggled to explain the brutality: 'I don’t have words...Nothing is real anymore.'

item.title: Why is Ukraine’s Donbas region a target for Russian forces?
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall
item.description: Russia is preparing to formally claim vast new swaths of Ukrainian territory, including the eastern Ukrainian regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, the United States said.

item.title: World leaders alarmed by possible overturn of Roe v. Wade
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis
item.description: A leaked Supreme Court draft opinion prompted calls from abroad to protect women's rights in the United States and around the world.

item.title: Russian TV shows simulation of Britain and Ireland wiped out by a nuke
item.dc:creator: Mary Ilyushina
item.description: A top Kremlin propagandist warned — without citing evidence — that Russia could send a nuclear-armed underwater drone or ballistic missile to sink the British Isles.

item.title: Norman Mineta, transportation secretary who helped create TSA, dies at 90
item.dc:creator: Emma Brown
item.description: The former California congressman also fought for reparations for Japanese Americans who, like him, had been in internment camps during World War II.

item.title: How abortion laws in the U.S. compare with those in other countries
item.dc:creator: Daniela Santamariña
item.description: Chief Justice Roberts said Mississippi’s 15-week abortion ban was 'the standard’ around the world. The reality is more complicated. As access has declined in many states, including Texas, other countries have made it easier.

item.title: What Victory Day means for Russian identity
item.dc:creator: Lateshia Beachum
item.description: May 9, known as Victory Day for Russians, could signal the end of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine or something more frightful that’s unlikely to halt the violence, but it's all speculation at this point.

item.title: CIA instructs Russians on how to share secrets with the spy agency
item.dc:creator: Shane Harris
item.description: The CIA published instructions for how Russians disaffected by the Ukraine war can covertly volunteer information using an encrypted conduit to the agency’s website.

item.title: Howitzer delivery to Taiwan delayed by strained U.S. supply chain
item.dc:creator: Christian Shepherd
item.description: The delays are a blow to Taiwan's efforts to build up its military in the face of increasing Chinese assertiveness.

item.title: Russia planning to annex new areas of Ukraine, U.S. intelligence finds
item.dc:creator: Missy Ryan
item.description: Claiming Donetsk, Luhansk and Kherson would be an attempt by Russia to control of much of Ukraine’s east despite ongoing struggles on the battlefield.

item.title: Three dozen tycoons met Putin on invasion day. Most had moved money abroad.
item.dc:creator: Peter Whoriskey
item.description: Three dozen tycoons met Putin on invasion day. Pandora Papers and Paradise Papers reveal how Russia’s richest businessmen have transferred wealth offshore.

item.title: Britain to send armored vehicles to Ukraine for civilian evacuations
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit
item.description: Britain announced the armored vehicles would go to Ukraine’s east as Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressed its parliament.

item.title: German chancellor rejects Kyiv visit — but his main rival is set to go
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.description: Ukraine said “war is not a kindergarten” after Chancellor Olaf Scholz declined to visit because of Volodymyr Zelensky’s snub of the German president.

item.title: As Egypt frees prisoners, fears grow for prominent activist left behind
item.dc:creator: Siobhán O'Grady
item.description: Egypt has recently freed some prisoners. But Alaa Abdel Fattah, one of Egypt’s most famous imprisoned dissidents and a symbol of the country’s 2011 revolt, has yet to win a reprieve.

item.title: Coming of age in a war, one Ukrainian teen finds her ‘mission’
item.dc:creator: Hannah Allam
item.description: At 16 and suddenly a grown-up, Anna volunteers to comfort the displaced: “Every day I wake up and think, ‘Okay, I can do something.’ ”

item.title: U.S. warns Russia may annex more Ukrainian territory
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault
item.description: U.S. diplomats will resume limited activities in Lviv. Nancy Pelosi meets the Polish president. Jill Biden to travel to Romania and Slovakia.

item.title: Culture, interrupted: Artists and artistic freedom in Russia face dark times
item.dc:creator: Mary Ilyushina
item.description: These are dark times in a country with one of the world’s richest cultural legacies. As Russia wages its war on Ukraine, the Kremlin is cracking down to quell dissent within its own borders.

item.title: Brazil's Senate to investigate after alleged Yanomami rape
item.dc:creator: Fabiano Maisonnave | AP
item.description: The Human Rights Committee of the Brazilian Senate is sending a team to Yanomami territory in the Amazon rainforest after reports that a 12-year-old Indigenous girl was raped and murdered

item.title: German opposition leader visits Kyiv, Scholz refuses to go
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Germany’s conservative opposition leader has traveled to Kyiv for meetings with Ukrainian officials including President Volodymyr Zelenskyy

item.title: Ukrainian band teams up with Ed Sheeran for charity single
item.dc:creator: Louise Dixon | AP
item.description: Ukrainian band Antytila has collaborated with Ed Sheeran on a single for charity

item.title: Dominican diplomat apparently kidnapped in Haiti
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: A diplomat from the Dominican Republic apparently has been kidnapped in neighboring Haiti

item.title: Yazidis, displaced again, fear more strife in Iraqi homeland
item.dc:creator: Rashid Yahya and Samya Kullab | AP
item.description: Internally displaced minority Yazidis say they are reluctant to return to their ancestral homeland in northern Iraq

item.title: Mexico relocates migrant camp; Haitians appear at border
item.dc:creator: MarÍa Verza | AP
item.description: Mexican authorities have relocated a migrant camp that sprung up in a park in the border city of Reynosa

item.title: Ethiopia detains 76 over Eid al-Fitr prayer unrest
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Ethiopian officials say they have arrested 76 suspects following unrest that erupted in the capital, Addis Ababa, during Eid al-Fitr prayers

item.title: Nigerian president says hostages being used as human shields
item.dc:creator: Chinedu Asadu | AP
item.description: Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari says dozens of people abducted from a passenger train near the nation’s capital in March are being used as “human shields” by their captors

item.title: Iran gets opportunity to sell auto parts to Russian carmaker
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: State media is reporting that a member of Iran’s syndicate of car parts manufacturers says Iranian producers have an opportunity to export their wares to a Russian carmaker

item.title: In Mexico, an entire town has its cross to bear
item.dc:creator: Fernanda Pesce | AP
item.description: Dozens of men strain and struggle as they heft a huge cross adorned with colorful ribbons and trudge down a steep hill followed by a multitude of townsfolk
